anchor.surface_text: Mr. B. Sen, learned counsel for the respondents, contended that this Court should decline to review its earlier judgment because it cannot be said that the earlier decision was clearly erroneous. He drew our attention to the judgment of a Bench of seven Judges in Keshav Mills v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 2  where Gajendragadkar, J., speaking for the Court observed at page 921 When this Court decides questions of law, its decisions are, under art. 141, binding on all courts within the territory of India...

concepts.interpretation: Court hesitates to overrule earlier decisions unless clearly erroneous with fair unanimity; consider if vital points unnoticed, relevant provisions missed; avoid uncertainty (court applies to decline overruling Parikh).

arguments.claim: An order under s.23A does not assess income, profits or gains as such but levies super tax on a certain portion of the undistributed profits and gains already assessed; taxable event is non-distribution of already assessed profits.

anchor.surface_text: In our view an order under S. 23A does number assess income, profits or gains as such but what it does is to levy super tax on a certain portion of the undistributed profits and gains. The section gives indications how this amount is arrived at and it is number necessary to deal with those matters. Further, this order is made following the expiry of the previous year as the Income-tax Officer has to take into companysideration the dividend distributed within 12 months following the expiry of the previous year the profits and gains of which are being companysidered. In other words the taxable event is number-distribution of some part of profits, which have already been assessed.

holdings.text: The judgment in M. M. Parikh v. Navanagar Transport Industries is not clearly erroneous and this Court declines to review or overrule it.

anchor.surface_text: He has not been able to convince us that the judgment  1  63 I.T.R. 663.  2  1965 2 S.C.R, 908, 921.  is clearly erroneous. Accordingly we must decline to review the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Counsel failed to demonstrate any vital points overlooked or that the decision was clearly erroneous; principles from Keshav Mills guide restraint in overruling precedents to maintain certainty.

holdings.text: An order under section 23A (as it stood before amendment by Finance Act 11 of 1957) is not an order of assessment or reassessment to which the limitation in section 34(3) applies, affirming M. M. Parikh.

anchor.surface_text: In M. M. Parikh v. Navanagar Transport Industries 1  it was held that an order under section 23A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, as amended by the Finance Acts of 1955 and 1957, made by the Income-tax Officer directing payment of additional super-tax is not an order of assessment within the meaning of s. 34(3) of the Act, and to such an order the period of limitation prescribed under section 34(3) does not apply.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior Supreme Court precedent in Parikh directly holds that s.23A orders are not assessments under s.34(3); current Bench declines to overrule after consideration.

holdings.text: The words in S. 34(3) 'after the expiry of four years from the end of the year in which the income, profits or gains were first assessable' are not really apposite to cover an order made under s. 23A.

anchor.surface_text: We may, however, add that one point which was not noticed by this Court in M. M. Parikhs 1  case or in the judgment of the High Court of Gujarat, appealed from in that case  Nava- nagar Industries Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer, Special Investigation Circle, Ahmedabad   1  tends to show that the case was correctly decided. It seems to us that the words after the expiry of four years from the end of the year in which the income, profits or gains were first assessable in S. 34 3  are not really apposite to cover the order made under s. 23A,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.34(3) language does not fit s.23A orders, as the profits are already assessed; point supports correctness of Parikh though unnoticed earlier.

holdings.text: An order under S. 23A does not assess income, profits or gains as such but levies super tax on a certain portion of the undistributed profits and gains already assessed; the taxable event is non-distribution of profits already assessed.

anchor.surface_text: In our view an order under S. 23A does not assess income, profits or gains as such but what it does is to levy super tax on a certain portion of the undistributed profits and gains. The section gives indications how this amount is arrived at and it is not necessary to deal with those matters. Further, this order is made following the expiry of the previous year as the Income-tax Officer has to take into consideration the dividend distributed within 12 months following the expiry of the previous year the profits and gains of which are being considered. In other words the taxable event is non-distribution of some part of profits, which have already been assessed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.23A operates on previously assessed profits post-year-end, considering dividends distributed later; levies tax on undistributed portion without re-assessing income.

anchor.surface_text: M. M. Parikh v. Navanagar Transport Industries 1 . The order impugned in the application is dated May 13, 1964. By this order the Income-tax Officer stated that on scrutiny of the records for the year of account relevant to the assessment year 1955-56 it has been numbericed that the Company did number declare any dividends at its general meeting, even though there were sufficient profits available for doing so and that there were numberlosses incurred in the earlier years.

anchor.surface_text: M. M. Parikhs 1  case was clearly erroneous and it should be overruled and relief granted to his client. Mr. B. Sen, learned counsel for the respondents, contended that this Court should decline to review its earlier judgment because it cannot be said that the earlier decision was clearly erroneous. He drew our attention to the judgment of a Bench of seven Judges in Keshav Mills v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 2  where Gajendragadkar, J., speaking for the Court observed at page 921 When this Court decides questions of law, its decisions are, under art. 141, binding on all courts within the territory of India, and so, it must be the constant endeavor and concern of this Court to introduce and maintain an element of certainty and continuity in the interpretation of law in the country.

precedents.case_name: M. M. Parikh v. Navanagar Transport Industries
precedents.cited_proposition: judgment said to be erroneous by appellant's counsel

precedents.citation: Keshav Mills v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 2

anchor.surface_text: Keshav Mills v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 2  where Gajendragadkar, J., speaking for the Court observed at page 921 When this Court decides questions of law, its decisions are, under art. 141, binding on all courts within the territory of India, and so, it must be the constant endeavor and concern of this Court to introduce and maintain an element of certainty and continuity in the interpretation of law in the country. Frequent exercise by this Court of its power to review its earlier decisions on the ground that the view pressed before it later appears to the Court to be more reasonable, may incidentally tend to make law uncertain and introduce confusion which must be consistently avoided.

precedents.case_name: Keshav Mills v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: when this Court should review its earlier decisions; only if clearly erroneous, considering unnoticed aspects, statutory provisions, previous decisions etc.
precedents.cited_holding: if on a subsequent occasion, the Court is satisfied that its earlier decision was clearly erroneous, it should hesitate to correct the error but before a previous decision is pronounced to be plainly erroneous, the Court must be satisfied with a fair amount of unanimity amongst its members that a revision of the said view is fully justified

anchor.surface_text: 1  63 I.T.R. 663.  2 1965 2 S.C.R, 908, 921. is clearly erroneous. Accordingly we must decline to review the case. We may, however, add that one point which was number numbericed by this Court in M. M. Parikhs 1  case or in the judgment of the High Court of Gujarat, appealed from in that case  Nava- nagar Industries Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer, Special Investigation Circle, Ahmedabad   1  tends to show that the case was companyrectly decided. It seems to us that the words after the expiry of four years from the end of the year in which the income, profits or gains were first assessable in S. 34(3) are not really apposite to cover the order made under s. 23A, as it stood before its amendment by the Finance Act 11 of, 1957.

precedents.case_name: M. M. Parikh v. Navanagar Transport Industries

anchor.surface_text: M. M. Parikhs 1  case or in the judgment of the High Court of Gujarat, appealed from in that case  Nava- nagar Industries Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer, Special Investigation Circle, Ahmedabad   1  tends to show that the case was companyrectly decided. It seems to us that the words after the expiry of four years from the end of the year in which the income, profits or gains were first assessable in S. 34(3) are number really apposite to cover the order made under s. 23A, as it stood before its amendment by the Finance Act 11 of, 1957. Section 34(3), without the proviso, at the relevant time read as follows 34(3) No order of assessment or re- assessment, other than an order of assessment under section 23 to which clause (c) of subsection (1) of section 28 applies or an order of assessment or reassessment in cases falling within clause (a) of sub-section (1A) of this section shall be made after the expiry of four years from the end of the year in which the income,, profits or gains were first assessable.

precedents.case_name: M. M. Parikh v. Navanagar Transport Industries
precedents.cited_proposition: point not noticed by this Court in [Parikh case]

precedents.citation: Nava- nagar Industries Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer, Special Investigation Circle, Ahmedabad   1

anchor.surface_text: Nava- nagar Industries Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer, Special Investigation Circle, Ahmedabad   1  tends to show that the case was companyrectly decided. It seems to us that the words after the expiry of four years from the end of the year in which the income, profits or gains were first assessable in S. 34(3) are number really apposite to cover the order made under s. 23A, as it stood before its amendment by the Finance Act 11 of, 1957. Section 34(3), without the proviso, at the relevant time read as follows 34(3) No order of assessment or re- assessment, other than an order of assessment under section 23 to which clause (c) of subsection (1) of section 28 applies or an order of assessment or reassessment in cases falling within clause (a) of sub-section (1A) of this section shall be made after the expiry of four years from the end of the year in which the income,, profits or gains were first assessable. In our view an order under S. 23A does number assess income, profits or gains as such but what it does is to levy super tax on a certain portion of the undistributed profits and gains.

precedents.case_name: Navanagar Industries Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer, Special Investigation Circle, Ahmedabad

anchor.surface_text: In M. M. Parikh v. Navanagar Transport Industries 1  it was held that an order under section 23A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, as amended by the Finance Acts of 1955 and 1957, made by the Income-tax Officer directing payment of additional super-tax is not an order of assessment within the meaning of s. 34(3) of the Act, and to such an order the period of limitation prescribed under section 34(3) does not apply.
Accordingly we must decline to review the case.

edges.explanation: Holding h3 supports concept c10 by providing reasoning why section 34(3) limitation does not apply to section 23A orders.
Holding h3 on the inaptness of section 34(3) words supports holding h2 that limitation does not apply to section 23A.

edges.explanation: Holding h3 addresses issue i4 by concluding the words are not apposite.

anchor.surface_text: We may, however, add that one point which was not noticed by this Court in M. M. Parikhs 1  case or in the judgment of the High Court of Gujarat, appealed from in that case  Nava- nagar Industries Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer, Special Investigation Circle, Ahmedabad   1  tends to show that the case was correctly decided. It seems to us that the words after the expiry of four years from the end of the year in which the income, profits or gains were first assessable in S. 34 3  are not really apposite to cover the order made under s. 23A,

anchor.surface_text: stood before its amendment by the Finance Act 11 of, 1957. Section 34 3 , without the proviso, at the relevant time read as follows 34 3  No order of

edges.explanation: h4 holds Section 23A levies super tax on undistributed profits already assessed without assessing income, addressing i3

anchor.surface_text: In our view an order under S. 23A does not assess income, profits or gains as such but what it does is to levy super tax on a certain portion of the undistributed profits and gains. The section gives indications how this amount is arrived at and it is not necessary to deal with those matters. Further, this order is made following the expiry of the previous year as the Income-tax Officer has to take into consideration the dividend distributed within 12 months following the expiry of the previous year the profits and gains of which are being considered. In other words the taxable event is non-distribution of some part of profits, which have already been assessed.

edges.explanation: Deciding whether to overrule a Supreme Court precedent in Parikh requires application of the doctrine on overruling precedents.
The issue explicitly questions whether the judgment in the precedent p1 (M. M. Parikh v. Navanagar Transport Industries) warrants overruling.
The precedent, by being upheld and not overruled, supports the holding declining review.
